docs.title: The Dukes Engineering Style Guide
docs.text: Version: 1.0.0 Maintainer: Tyler Dukes License: MIT Last Updated: 2025-10-27

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The Dukes Engineering Style Guide defines a unified, opinionated standard for writing infrastructure and application code that is both human-readable and AI-optimized. It is designed to create consistency across Terraform, Terragrunt, Ansible, Kubernetes, Bash, and Python ecosystems — enabling reproducible automation and long-term maintainability.

This guide reflects practical standards derived from real-world DevOps, SRE, and automation practices. Its intent is to strike the right balance between flexibility and rigor — allowing engineers to focus on building systems instead of debating style.

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text:
1. Clarity First: Code must communicate intent before it executes logic. Readability and maintainability take precedence over brevity.

  2. Automation by Default: Everything that can be automated — linting, formatting, testing, and deployment — is automated.

  3. Security and Stability: Secrets are always managed securely, dependencies are pinned, and environments are deterministic.

  4. Reproducibility: Builds, tests, and deployments must produce consistent outcomes across local, CI, and production environments.

  5. Human + AI Collaboration: Every standard is designed for dual readability — equally interpretable by developers and AI assistants.

docs.title: Scope
docs.text:
This guide provides style and structure conventions for the following domains:

  • Infrastructure as Code (IaC): Terraform with Terragrunt, Ansible, Kubernetes YAMLs
  • Scripting: Bash and PowerShell
  • Application Code: Python, Node.js, TypeScript, Go, Groovy
  • Pipelines: Declarative Jenkins, CI/CD YAML, GitHub Actions
  • Data and Querying: SQL and related database scripts

Each section defines:

  • Standardized formatting rules
  • Naming conventions
  • Directory and module structure
  • Security and secret management practices
  • Documentation expectations
  • AI-annotation standards (metadata blocks and comment schemas)

docs.title: Document Structure
docs.text:
Section Description 1. Foundations Global principles, file structure, documentation format 2. Language Guides Specific rules for Python, Bash, Terraform, and others 3. Automation & Testing Pre-commit, linting, CI/CD, and test orchestration 4. AI Metadata Comment schemas, structured annotations, and promptable code 5. Templates & Samples Example repositories, starter modules, and CI workflows

Each section is modular and self-contained, allowing this guide to evolve alongside your toolchain.

docs.title: How to Use This Guide
docs.text:
• For human readers, this guide acts as a living documentation of your engineering standards.
  • For AI models, embedded metadata blocks and clear structure enable code generation, refactoring, and auditing with minimal ambiguity.

docs.title: Versioning Policy
docs.text:
This project follows Semantic Versioning:

  • MAJOR version: Incompatible changes to validation rules or container interface
  • MINOR version: New features, language guides, or significant documentation additions
  • PATCH version: Bug fixes, dependency updates, documentation improvements

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: This glossary defines terms used throughout the Dukes Engineering Style Guide, including technical concepts, tool names, metadata tags, and industry terminology.

docs.title: AI Assistant
docs.text: A software tool that uses artificial intelligence to help with code writing, review, and understanding. Examples include Claude, GitHub Copilot, and ChatGPT. The style guide optimizes code metadata for better AI comprehension.

docs.title: Ansible
docs.text: An open-source automation tool for configuration management, application deployment, and task automation. Uses YAML playbooks to define infrastructure as code.

docs.title: API (Application Programming Interface)
docs.text: A set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate with each other. Commonly refers to RESTful HTTP APIs in web services.

docs.title: API Endpoint
docs.text: A specific URL path and HTTP method combination that provides access to a resource or function in an API. Example: POST /auth/login.

docs.title: Automation
docs.text: The use of tools and scripts to perform tasks automatically without manual intervention. Core principle of the style guide for enforcing standards.

docs.title: Bash
docs.text: Unix shell and command language used for scripting and automation. Commonly used for deployment scripts, CI/CD pipelines, and system administration tasks.

docs.title: Black
docs.text: An opinionated Python code formatter that automatically formats code to a consistent style. Eliminates debates about formatting by providing one standard style.

docs.title: Block Comment
docs.text: A multi-line comment enclosed in special syntax. Example in Terraform: /* comment */, in Python: """docstring""".

docs.title: Boolean
docs.text: A data type with two possible values: true or false. Often used for configuration flags and conditional logic.

docs.title: Branch
docs.text: A parallel version of a repository in version control. Allows development of features in isolation from the main codebase.

docs.title: Breaking Change
docs.text: A modification to code or API that is not backward-compatible and requires users to update their code. Triggers a MAJOR version increment in semantic versioning.

docs.title: camelCase
docs.text: A naming convention where the first word is lowercase and subsequent words are capitalized. Example: getUserDetails. Common in JavaScript and TypeScript.

docs.title: CI/CD (Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment)
docs.text: Practices that automate the building, testing, and deployment of code. CI runs automated tests on every commit; CD automatically deploys passing code to production.

docs.title: CLI (Command-Line Interface)
docs.text: A text-based interface for interacting with software through commands typed into a terminal. Example: git commit -m "message".

docs.title: Code Review
docs.text: The process of examining code changes before they are merged, typically through pull requests. Focuses on logic, architecture, and design rather than formatting.

docs.title: Container
docs.text: A lightweight, standalone package of software that includes everything needed to run an application: code, runtime, libraries, and dependencies. Docker is the most common container platform.

docs.title: Convention
docs.text: An agreed-upon standard or pattern used consistently across a codebase. Examples include naming conventions and code structure patterns.

docs.title: Dependency
docs.text: An external library, package, or module that code relies on to function. Should be documented in metadata tags.

docs.title: Deployment
docs.text: The process of releasing software to a target environment (production, staging, or development).

docs.title: Deprecation
docs.text: Marking a feature, function, or module as obsolete and scheduled for removal. Uses @status deprecated metadata tag.

docs.title: Development Environment
docs.text: The local or remote system where developers write and test code, typically with debugging tools and test data.

docs.title: DevOps
docs.text: A set of practices that combines software development (Dev) and IT operations (Ops) to shorten development cycles and deliver high-quality software.

docs.title: Docker
docs.text: A platform for developing, shipping, and running applications in containers. Ensures consistency across development, testing, and production environments.

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text: Written explanations of how code works, including inline comments, README files, and generated API docs. Auto-generated from metadata in this style guide.

docs.title: Dry Run
docs.text: Executing a command in simulation mode without making actual changes. Useful for testing potentially destructive operations.

docs.title: EditorConfig
docs.text: A file format and collection of editor plugins for maintaining consistent coding styles across different editors and IDEs.

docs.title: Environment Variable
docs.text: A dynamic value that can affect how processes behave on a computer. Often used to configure applications without hardcoding values. Example: API_KEY=abc123.

docs.title: EOF (End of File)
docs.text: A marker indicating the end of a file. Files should end with exactly one blank line per style guide convention.

docs.title: ESLint
docs.text: A static analysis tool for identifying problematic patterns in JavaScript/TypeScript code. Enforces code quality and style rules.

docs.title: Feature Branch
docs.text: A git branch created to develop a specific feature in isolation. Named with feature/ prefix. Example: feature/add-user-auth.

docs.title: Flake8
docs.text: A Python linting tool that checks code for style violations, programming errors, and complexity. Combines pycodestyle, pyflakes, and McCabe.

docs.title: Formatter
docs.text: A tool that automatically reformats code to match style guidelines. Examples include Black (Python), Prettier (JavaScript/TypeScript), and terraform fmt.

docs.title: Function
docs.text: A reusable block of code that performs a specific task. Should be named with verb-noun format: get_user(), calculate_total().

docs.title: Git
docs.text: A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.

docs.title: GitHub Actions
docs.text: A CI/CD platform that automates workflows directly in GitHub repositories. Used for testing, building, and deploying code.

docs.title: GitFlow
docs.text: A branching model for Git that uses specific branch types (main, develop, feature, release, hotfix) with strict merge rules.

docs.title: GitLab CI
docs.text: GitLab's integrated CI/CD platform. Uses .gitlab-ci.yml configuration files to define pipelines.

docs.title: Glob Pattern
docs.text: A pattern-matching syntax using wildcards. Example: **/*.py matches all Python files in all subdirectories.

docs.title: Groovy
docs.text: A dynamic programming language for the Java platform. Used for Jenkins pipeline scripts and Gradle build files.

docs.title: Hash Comment
docs.text: A single-line comment starting with #. Used in Python, Bash, YAML, Terraform, and other languages.

docs.title: HCL (HashiCorp Configuration Language)
docs.text: The configuration language used by Terraform and other HashiCorp tools. Declarative syntax for defining infrastructure.

docs.title: Helm
docs.text: A package manager for Kubernetes that uses charts to define, install, and upgrade Kubernetes applications.

docs.title: Hook
docs.text: A script or command that runs automatically in response to specific events. Examples include pre-commit hooks and CI/CD hooks.

docs.title: Hotfix Branch
docs.text: A git branch created from main to fix critical production bugs. Named with hotfix/ prefix. Must be merged to both main and develop.

docs.title: IAC (Infrastructure as Code)
docs.text: Managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable definition files rather than manual configuration. Examples: Terraform, Ansible.

docs.title: IDE (Integrated Development Environment)
docs.text: Software application providing comprehensive facilities for software development. Examples: VSCode, PyCharm, IntelliJ IDEA.

docs.title: Idempotent
docs.text: An operation that produces the same result no matter how many times it's executed. Important for automation and infrastructure code.

docs.title: Import
docs.text: Including code from external modules or libraries. Should be organized by type: standard library, third-party, local modules.

docs.title: Inline Comment
docs.text: A comment on the same line as code or immediately above it. Should explain why, not what.

docs.title: ISO 8601
docs.text: International standard for date and time formats. Used for @last_updated metadata tag. Example: 2025-10-28.

docs.title: Jenkins
docs.text: An open-source automation server for building, testing, and deploying software. Uses Groovy for pipeline definitions.

docs.title: JSDoc
docs.text: A markup language for annotating JavaScript and TypeScript code with documentation comments. Uses /** ... */ syntax.

docs.title: JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)
docs.text: A lightweight data interchange format. Human-readable text to store and transmit data objects. Common for configuration files.

docs.title: JWT (JSON Web Token)
docs.text: A compact, URL-safe means of representing claims between two parties. Commonly used for authentication in web applications.

docs.title: kebab-case
docs.text: A naming convention where words are lowercase and separated by hyphens. Example: user-authentication. Common for file names and URLs.

docs.title: Kubernetes
docs.text: An open-source container orchestration platform for automating deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications.

docs.title: Language Server Protocol (LSP)
docs.text: A protocol between editors and language servers that provides IDE features like autocomplete, go-to-definition, and refactoring.

docs.title: Linter
docs.text: A static code analysis tool that checks for programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors, and suspicious constructs. Examples: Flake8, ESLint, ShellCheck.

docs.title: Logging
docs.text: The process of recording events, errors, and information during program execution. Essential for debugging and monitoring.

docs.title: MAJOR Version
docs.text: The first number in semantic versioning (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Incremented for incompatible API changes or breaking changes.

docs.title: Main Branch
docs.text: The primary branch in a Git repository containing production-ready code. Protected from direct commits.

docs.title: Makefile
docs.text: A file containing commands and dependencies for build automation using the make command. Organizes common development tasks.

docs.title: Metadata
docs.text: Data that provides information about other data. In this style guide, structured tags in code comments describing modules, versions, dependencies, etc.

docs.title: MINOR Version
docs.text: The second number in semantic versioning (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Incremented for new backward-compatible functionality.

docs.title: Mocking
docs.text: Creating fake objects or responses for testing purposes. Allows testing code in isolation without external dependencies.

docs.title: Module
docs.text: A self-contained unit of code with a specific purpose. Should include @module metadata tag with unique identifier.

docs.title: Monorepo
docs.text: A single repository containing multiple projects or services. Contrast with multi-repo where each project has its own repository.

docs.title: MkDocs
docs.text: A static site generator for building project documentation from Markdown files. Used for this style guide's documentation site.

docs.title: Multi-repo
docs.text: Repository organization pattern where each project or service has its own separate repository. Contrast with monorepo.

docs.title: Mypy
docs.text: A static type checker for Python that uses type hints to catch type-related errors before runtime.

docs.title: Naming Convention
docs.text: Rules for naming variables, functions, classes, and files. Varies by language but should be consistent within a codebase.

docs.title: NAT Gateway
docs.text: Network Address Translation gateway in AWS VPC that allows instances in private subnets to access the internet.

docs.title: Node.js
docs.text: JavaScript runtime built on Chrome's V8 engine. Allows running JavaScript on the server side.

docs.title: npm (Node Package Manager)
docs.text: Package manager for JavaScript. Used to install, manage, and publish Node.js packages.

docs.title: OAuth
docs.text: Open standard for access delegation, commonly used for token-based authentication. Allows third-party services to exchange information without sharing passwords.

docs.title: OOP (Object-Oriented Programming)
docs.text: Programming paradigm based on the concept of objects containing data and code. Languages: Python, Java, TypeScript.

docs.title: PascalCase
docs.text: A naming convention where every word starts with an uppercase letter. Example: UserAuthentication. Used for class names.

docs.title: PATCH Version
docs.text: The third number in semantic versioning (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Incremented for backward-compatible bug fixes.

docs.title: Pipeline
docs.text: A sequence of automated processes in CI/CD. Each stage performs specific tasks like building, testing, and deploying.

docs.title: PowerShell
docs.text: A task automation framework from Microsoft consisting of a command-line shell and scripting language. Used for Windows system administration.

docs.title: Pre-commit Hook
docs.text: A script that runs automatically before a commit is created. Used to enforce code quality standards before code enters version control.

docs.title: Prettier
docs.text: An opinionated code formatter for JavaScript, TypeScript, JSON, YAML, and other languages. Ensures consistent formatting across projects.

docs.title: Pull Request (PR)
docs.text: A method of submitting contributions to a project. Allows code review and discussion before merging changes into the main branch.

docs.title: Python
docs.text: A high-level, interpreted programming language known for readability and versatility. Used for web development, data analysis, automation, and more.

docs.title: Quality Gate
docs.text: A set of conditions that code must meet before being merged or deployed. May include test coverage, code quality metrics, and security scans.

docs.title: README
docs.text: A text file containing information about a project. Typically the first file users see when visiting a repository. Should include setup instructions and usage examples.

docs.title: Refactoring
docs.text: Restructuring existing code without changing its external behavior. Improves code readability, maintainability, or performance.

docs.title: Regex (Regular Expression)
docs.text: A sequence of characters defining a search pattern. Used for text searching, validation, and parsing.

docs.title: Release Branch
docs.text: A git branch created from develop to prepare a new production release. Named with release/ prefix. Example: release/v1.3.0.

docs.title: Repository
docs.text: A storage location for code managed by version control. Contains all project files, history, and branches.

docs.title: REST (Representational State Transfer)
docs.text: An architectural style for web services that uses HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) to interact with resources.

docs.title: Rollback
docs.text: Reverting to a previous version of code or infrastructure after a problematic deployment.

docs.title: Script
docs.text: A program written in a scripting language (Bash, Python, PowerShell) to automate tasks.

docs.title: Semantic Versioning
docs.text: A versioning scheme using three numbers (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH) with defined rules for incrementing each. Used throughout this style guide.

docs.title: ShellCheck
docs.text: A static analysis tool for shell scripts. Identifies common errors and provides suggestions for improvement.

docs.title: Slack Integration
docs.text: Connecting a service to Slack for notifications and automation. Common in CI/CD pipelines for build status updates.

docs.title: snake_case
docs.text: A naming convention where words are lowercase and separated by underscores. Example: user_authentication. Common in Python and database fields.

docs.title: SonarQube
docs.text: A platform for continuous inspection of code quality. Performs automatic reviews with static analysis to detect bugs and code smells.

docs.title: SQL (Structured Query Language)
docs.text: A domain-specific language for managing data in relational databases. Used for querying, updating, and managing databases.

docs.title: Staging Environment
docs.text: A replica of the production environment used for final testing before deployment. Should match production configuration closely.

docs.title: Static Analysis
docs.text: Examining code without executing it to find potential errors, security vulnerabilities, and style violations.

docs.title: Status
docs.text: The current state of a module or feature. Valid values: draft, in-progress, review, stable, deprecated, archived. Documented with @status metadata tag.

docs.title: Strict Mode
docs.text: A configuration option that treats warnings as errors and enforces stricter validation rules. Example: mkdocs build --strict.

docs.title: Stub
docs.text: A minimal implementation of a function or module used during testing. Provides predetermined responses without real logic.

docs.title: Tag
docs.text: A named reference to a specific commit in Git. Used for marking releases. Example: v1.0.0.

docs.title: Terraform
docs.text: An infrastructure as code tool that allows defining cloud and on-premises resources in declarative configuration files.

docs.title: Terragrunt
docs.text: A thin wrapper for Terraform that provides extra tools for keeping configurations DRY, managing remote state, and working with multiple modules.

docs.title: Test Coverage
docs.text: A measure of how much code is executed during testing. Expressed as a percentage. Minimum 80% recommended for business logic.

docs.title: tflint
docs.text: A linter for Terraform that finds possible errors, warns about deprecated syntax, and enforces best practices.

docs.title: Type Checker
docs.text: A tool that verifies type correctness in code. Examples: mypy (Python), tsc (TypeScript).

docs.title: TypeScript
docs.text: A strongly typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript. Adds static type definitions to JavaScript.

docs.title: Unit Test
docs.text: A test that verifies a small, isolated piece of code (typically a single function or method) works correctly.

docs.title: UpperCamelCase
docs.text: See PascalCase. A naming convention where every word starts with an uppercase letter.

docs.title: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE
docs.text: A naming convention where words are uppercase and separated by underscores. Example: API_KEY. Used for constants.

docs.title: uv
docs.text: A fast Python package installer and resolver. Modern alternative to pip with improved performance and better dependency resolution.

docs.title: Validation
docs.text: The process of checking that data, code, or configurations meet specified requirements and constraints.

docs.title: Variable
docs.text: A named storage location in a program that holds a value that can be changed during execution.

docs.title: Version Control
docs.text: A system for tracking changes to files over time. Allows reverting to previous versions and collaborating with multiple developers. Git is the most common version control system.

docs.title: VPC (Virtual Private Cloud)
docs.text: An isolated virtual network within a cloud provider (like AWS). Provides security and control over network configuration.

docs.title: Webhook
docs.text: An HTTP callback that sends real-time data from one application to another when a specific event occurs. Common in CI/CD pipelines.

docs.title: Whitespace
docs.text: Characters that represent horizontal or vertical space in text: spaces, tabs, and newlines. Proper whitespace improves code readability.

docs.title: Workflow
docs.text: A sequence of steps to accomplish a task, often automated in CI/CD systems.

docs.title: YAML (YAML Ain't Markup Language)
docs.text: A human-readable data serialization language. Common for configuration files in Ansible, Kubernetes, GitHub Actions, and more.

docs.title: yamllint
docs.text: A linter for YAML files that checks syntax and enforces style rules.

docs.title: @api_endpoints
docs.text: Documents HTTP API routes exposed by a module. Format: comma-separated list of METHOD /path pairs.

docs.title: @author
docs.text: The original creator or primary maintainer of a module. Helps with accountability and knowledge transfer.

docs.title: @dependencies
docs.text: External libraries, packages, or modules required for the code to function. Can include version constraints.

docs.title: @depends_on
docs.text: Internal module or file dependencies using relative paths. Shows relationships between code modules.

docs.title: @description
docs.text: A clear, concise explanation of what the module does. Should start with a verb and avoid implementation details.

docs.title: @env
docs.text: Target deployment environments for the module. Common values: prod, staging, dev, test.

docs.title: @last_updated
docs.text: Date of the last significant update to the module. Format: YYYY-MM-DD (ISO 8601).

docs.title: @license
docs.text: The software license governing the code. Examples: MIT, Apache-2.0, GPL-3.0.

docs.title: @module
docs.text: Unique identifier for a code module or file. Should be descriptive and use lowercase with underscores or hyphens.

docs.title: @python_version
docs.text: Minimum Python version required. Format: >= 3.9. Used for Python modules.

docs.title: @security_classification
docs.text: Data sensitivity level. Values: public, internal, confidential, restricted.

docs.title: @status
docs.text: Current development or deployment status. Values: draft, in-progress, review, stable, deprecated, archived.

docs.title: @terraform_version
docs.text: Minimum Terraform version required. Format: >= 1.0. Used for Terraform modules.

docs.title: @version
docs.text: Semantic version of the module (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH). Updated according to the type of changes made.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Welcome to the Dukes Engineering Style Guide! This guide will help you quickly adopt consistent coding standards, automated validation, and AI-friendly metadata across your projects.

docs.title: What is This Style Guide?
docs.text:
The Dukes Engineering Style Guide is a comprehensive, multi-language coding standard that:

  • Enforces consistency through automated tooling (linters, formatters, validators)
  • Optimizes for AI with structured metadata that helps AI assistants understand your code
  • Supports multiple languages (Python, Terraform, Bash, TypeScript, SQL, and more)
  • Provides validation through pre-commit hooks, CI/CD pipelines, and containerized workflows
  • Documents automatically using metadata tags for auto-generated documentation

docs.title: Who Should Use This?
docs.text:
This style guide is ideal for:

  • DevOps Engineers working with infrastructure as code (Terraform, Ansible, Kubernetes)
  • Software Engineers building APIs, services, and applications
  • Teams looking for consistent coding standards across languages
  • Projects that want to leverage AI assistants more effectively
  • Organizations needing automated code quality enforcement

docs.title: 1. Add Metadata to a File
docs.text:
Add metadata tags to your code files using language-appropriate comment syntax:

Python Example:

"""
@module user_authentication
@description Handles user login, session management, and JWT token generation
@version 1.0.0
@author Your Name
@last_updated 2025-10-28
@dependencies fastapi, pyjwt
@status stable
"""

import jwt
from fastapi import APIRouter

# Your code here...

Terraform Example:

/**
 * @module vpc_networking
 * @description Creates AWS VPC with public/private subnets and NAT gateways
 * @version 2.0.0
 * @author Your Name
 * @last_updated 2025-10-28
 * @dependencies aws_vpc, aws_subnet, aws_nat_gateway
 * @status stable
 */

resource "aws_vpc" "main" {
  cidr_block = var.vpc_cidr
  # Your configuration...
}

docs.title: 2. Validate Metadata
docs.text:
Use the validator to check your metadata:

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/tydukes/coding-style-guide.git
cd coding-style-guide

# Validate your files
python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py /path/to/your/project

# Or validate specific language files
python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py --language python /path/to/your/src

docs.title: 3. Set Up Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
Add automated validation to your repository:

# Install pre-commit
pip install pre-commit

# Add .pre-commit-config.yaml to your repo
cat > .pre-commit-config.yaml <<EOF
repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/psf/black
    rev: 24.10.0
    hooks:
      - id: black
  - repo: https://github.com/pycqa/flake8
    rev: 7.1.1
    hooks:
      - id: flake8
  - repo: https://github.com/antonbabenko/pre-commit-terraform
    rev: v1.96.1
    hooks:
      - id: terraform_fmt
      - id: terraform_validate
  - repo: local
    hooks:
      - id: validate-metadata
        name: Validate Metadata
        entry: python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py
        language: python
        files: \.(py|tf|hcl|js|ts|sh|sql)$
EOF

# Install hooks
pre-commit install

That's it! Now your code will be validated automatically before every commit.

docs.title: Option 1: Local Installation
docs.text:
Prerequisites:

  • Python 3.8 or higher
  • Git

Steps:

  1. Clone the repository:

bash git clone https://github.com/tydukes/coding-style-guide.git cd coding-style-guide

  1. Install Python dependencies:

```bash # Using uv (recommended) pip install uv uv sync

# Or using pip pip install -r requirements.txt ```

  1. Run the documentation server locally:

bash uv run mkdocs serve # Access at http://127.0.0.1:8000

docs.title: Option 2: Container-Based
docs.text:
Prerequisites:

  • Docker

Steps:

  1. Pull the pre-built container:

bash docker pull ghcr.io/tydukes/coding-style-guide:latest

  1. Run validation on your project:

bash docker run --rm -v $(pwd):/workspace \ ghcr.io/tydukes/coding-style-guide:latest \ validate /workspace

  1. See available modes:

bash docker run --rm ghcr.io/tydukes/coding-style-guide:latest --help

Available Modes: - validate - Full validation (metadata + linting) - lint - Linting only - format - Auto-format files - docs - Build documentation - metadata - Metadata validation only

docs.title: Option 3: GitHub Actions Integration
docs.text:
Add to your .github/workflows/ci.yml:

name: Code Quality

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  validate:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Validate Code Standards
        uses: tydukes/coding-style-guide/.github/actions/validate@v1.0.0
        with:
          mode: validate  # validate, lint, format, docs, metadata
          path: .
          language: python  # Optional: python, terraform, bash, etc.

docs.title: 1. Understanding the Metadata Schema
docs.text:
All files should include metadata tags in their headers. The three required tags are:

  • @module - Unique identifier (lowercase with underscores or hyphens)
  • @description - Brief explanation of what the module does
  • @version - Semantic version (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH)

Recommended tags:

  • @author - Module creator
  • @last_updated - Date of last update (YYYY-MM-DD)
  • @dependencies - External dependencies

Optional tags:

  • @status - Development status (draft, stable, deprecated, etc.)
  • @security_classification - Security level (public, internal, confidential)
  • @api_endpoints - API routes exposed
  • @env - Target environments (prod, staging, dev)

See the Metadata Schema Reference for complete documentation.

docs.title: 2. Adding Metadata to Existing Code
docs.text:
Step 1: Identify files without metadata

cd coding-style-guide
python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py /path/to/your/project --output results.json

Step 2: Add minimal metadata

Start with the three required tags:

"""
@module [infer_from_filename]
@description [TODO: Add description]
@version 0.1.0
"""

Step 3: Progressively enhance

Add more tags as you go:

"""
@module user_service
@description Handles user account creation, authentication, and profile management
@version 1.0.0
@author Your Name
@last_updated 2025-10-28
@dependencies fastapi, sqlalchemy, pydantic
@status stable
"""

docs.title: 3. Running Validation
docs.text:
Validate all files:

python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py /path/to/project

Validate specific language:

python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py --language python src/
python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py --language terraform infrastructure/

Strict mode (warnings treated as errors):

python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py --strict /path/to/project

Export results to JSON:

python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py --output validation_results.json /path/to/project

docs.title: Use Case 1: New Project Setup
docs.text:
Goal: Start a new project with the style guide from day one.

Steps:

  1. Initialize your repository:

bash mkdir my-new-project cd my-new-project git init

  1. Copy the style guide configuration:

```bash # Copy pre-commit config curl -o .pre-commit-config.yaml \ https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tydukes/coding-style-guide/main/.pre-commit-config.yaml

# Install pre-commit pip install pre-commit pre-commit install ```

  1. Add metadata to your first file:

```python """ @module main @description Application entry point @version 0.1.0 @author Your Name @last_updated 2025-10-28 """

def main(): print("Hello, World!")

if name == "main": main() ```

  1. Commit and validate:

bash git add . git commit -m "feat: initial project setup with style guide"

docs.title: Use Case 2: Migrating Existing Project
docs.text:
Goal: Add the style guide to an existing codebase.

Steps:

  1. Run validation to see current state:

bash python3 /path/to/coding-style-guide/scripts/validate_metadata.py . --output baseline.json

  1. Create a migration plan:

```bash # Count files needing metadata jq '.errors | length' baseline.json

# Identify most critical files (entry points, APIs, core modules) ```

  1. Add metadata incrementally:

  2. Start with core modules (entry points, main services)

  3. Move to API endpoints and business logic

  4. Finally, utilities and helpers

  5. Set up pre-commit hooks:

bash pip install pre-commit # Copy .pre-commit-config.yaml from style guide pre-commit install

  1. Track progress:

```bash # Re-run validation periodically python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py . --output progress.json

# Compare error counts diff baseline.json progress.json ```

docs.title: Use Case 3: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
Goal: Enforce standards in your CI/CD pipeline.

GitHub Actions:

# .github/workflows/ci.yml
name: Code Quality

on: [push, pull_request]

jobs:
  validate:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4

      - name: Set up Python
        uses: actions/setup-python@v5
        with:
          python-version: '3.11'

      - name: Install dependencies
        run: |
          pip install black flake8 mypy
          pip install pre-commit

      - name: Run pre-commit
        run: pre-commit run --all-files

      - name: Validate metadata
        run: |
          git clone https://github.com/tydukes/coding-style-guide.git
          python3 coding-style-guide/scripts/validate_metadata.py . --strict

GitLab CI:

# .gitlab-ci.yml
validate:
  image: ghcr.io/tydukes/coding-style-guide:latest
  script:
    - validate /builds/$CI_PROJECT_PATH
  only:
    - merge_requests
    - main

docs.title: Issue: Pre-commit Hooks Failing
docs.text:
Symptom: Commit blocked with "black" or "flake8" errors

Solution:

# Run black to auto-format
black .

# Check flake8 errors
flake8 .

# Fix errors and try again
git add .
git commit -m "fix: address linting issues"

docs.title: Issue: Metadata Validation Failing
docs.text:
Symptom: validate_metadata.py reports missing or invalid tags

Solution:

# Check which files are failing
python3 scripts/validate_metadata.py . --output errors.json
cat errors.json | jq '.errors'

# Add missing tags
# Fix version format (use MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH)
# Fix date format (use YYYY-MM-DD)

docs.title: Issue: Duplicate Module Names
docs.text:
Symptom: Validator reports "Duplicate module name"

Solution:

# Find duplicates
grep -r "@module your_module_name" .

# Rename one of the modules to be unique
# Module names should describe the specific purpose

docs.title: Issue: Container Permission Denied
docs.text:
Symptom: Docker container can't write to mounted volume

Solution:

# Run with user permissions
docker run --rm -v $(pwd):/workspace \
  --user $(id -u):$(id -g) \
  ghcr.io/tydukes/coding-style-guide:latest \
  validate /workspace

docs.title: Q: Do I need to add metadata to every file?
docs.text: A: Yes, all code modules should have metadata. However, you can migrate incrementally - start with core modules and expand over time.

docs.title: Q: Can I customize the metadata schema?
docs.text: A: Yes! The schema is extensible. You can add custom tags for your organization's needs. Just document them and update your validation scripts.

docs.title: Q: What if my language isn't supported?
docs.text: A: The metadata schema is language-agnostic. Use the appropriate comment syntax for your language and follow the same tag format. You can also contribute a new language guide!

docs.title: Q: Do I need to use all the tools (Black, Flake8, etc.)?
docs.text: A: No, pick the tools that make sense for your project. At minimum, we recommend using the metadata validator and formatters for your primary languages.

docs.title: Q: How do I handle legacy code?
docs.text: A: Add metadata as you touch files. Use the @status deprecated tag for code that's being phased out. Consider creating a migration plan to add metadata incrementally.

docs.title: Q: Can I use this with monorepos?
docs.text:
A: Absolutely! The style guide works great with monorepos. See the Repository Structure guide for monorepo-specific patterns.

docs.title: Governance Model
docs.text: This document defines how the Dukes Engineering Style Guide is governed, including branching strategies, pull request requirements, release processes, and change management procedures. These governance rules ensure consistent quality, maintainability, and collaborative development.

docs.title: GitFlow Branching Model
docs.text: This repository follows GitFlow, a strict branching model that separates development work from stable releases.

docs.title: Main Branch (main)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Production-ready code only
  • Protection: Fully protected, no direct commits
  • Deployment: Automatically deploys documentation to GitHub Pages
  • Merges: Only from release branches or hotfix branches
  • Tags: All releases tagged with semantic versions (e.g., v1.2.0)

Protection Rules:

  • Require pull request reviews (minimum 1 approval)
  • Require status checks to pass (CI, linting, tests)
  • Require branches to be up to date before merging
  • Require signed commits (optional but recommended)
  • Restrict who can push (maintainers only)

docs.title: Development Branch (develop)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Integration branch for ongoing development
  • Protection: Protected, no direct commits
  • Merges: Feature branches merge here first
  • Testing: All features tested together before release
  • Stability: Should always be in a deployable state

Protection Rules:

  • Require pull request reviews
  • Require status checks to pass
  • Allow only maintainers to merge

docs.title: Feature Branches (feature/*)
docs.text:
• Purpose: New features, enhancements, documentation additions
  • Created from: develop (or main if no develop branch exists)
  • Merged to: develop (or main)
  • Naming: feature/<issue-number>-<short-description>
  • Lifetime: Deleted after merge

Examples:

feature/13-expand-principles-doc
feature/add-powershell-guide
feature/improve-metadata-schema

Workflow:

# Create feature branch
git checkout develop
git pull origin develop
git checkout -b feature/13-expand-principles-doc

# Make changes, commit
git add .
git commit -m "feat: expand principles documentation"

# Push and create PR
git push -u origin feature/13-expand-principles-doc
gh pr create --base develop

docs.title: Fix Branches (fix/*)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Bug fixes for non-critical issues
  • Created from: develop
  • Merged to: develop
  • Naming: fix/<issue-number>-<short-description>

Examples:

fix/42-correct-typo-in-terraform-guide
fix/broken-mkdocs-link

docs.title: Hotfix Branches (hotfix/*)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Critical bug fixes for production
  • Created from: main
  • Merged to: main AND develop
  • Naming: hotfix/<version>-<description>
  • Urgency: Bypass normal development cycle

Examples:

hotfix/v1.2.2-critical-security-fix
hotfix/v1.0.1-container-build-failure

Workflow:

# Create hotfix from main
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git checkout -b hotfix/v1.2.2-security-fix

# Fix the issue, commit
git add .
git commit -m "fix: critical security vulnerability in metadata parser"

# Merge to main
git checkout main
git merge --no-ff hotfix/v1.2.2-security-fix
git tag v1.2.2
git push origin main --tags

# Merge to develop
git checkout develop
git merge --no-ff hotfix/v1.2.2-security-fix
git push origin develop

# Delete hotfix branch
git branch -d hotfix/v1.2.2-security-fix

docs.title: Release Branches (release/*)
docs.text:
• Purpose: Prepare new production release
  • Created from: develop
  • Merged to: main AND develop
  • Naming: release/v<version>
  • Activities: Version bumps, changelog updates, final testing

Workflow:

# Create release branch
git checkout develop
git pull origin develop
git checkout -b release/v1.3.0

# Update version, changelog
# Run final tests
# Fix any last-minute issues

# Merge to main
git checkout main
git merge --no-ff release/v1.3.0
git tag v1.3.0
git push origin main --tags

# Merge back to develop
git checkout develop
git merge --no-ff release/v1.3.0
git push origin develop

# Delete release branch
git branch -d release/v1.3.0

docs.title: Branch Naming Conventions
docs.text:
Format: <type>/<scope>

Type Prefixes:

  • feature/ - New features, enhancements
  • fix/ - Bug fixes
  • hotfix/ - Critical production fixes
  • release/ - Release preparation
  • docs/ - Documentation-only changes
  • chore/ - Maintenance, dependency updates

Scope Guidelines:

  • Use issue number when applicable: feature/42-add-sql-guide
  • Use kebab-case for descriptions: feature/improve-error-handling
  • Keep concise (max 50 characters)

docs.title: Pull Request Process
docs.text: All changes to main and develop branches must go through pull requests.

docs.title: Required Checks
docs.text:
All PRs must pass these automated checks before merge:

  1. Linters:
  2. markdownlint (documentation)
  3. yamllint (YAML files)
  4. shellcheck (shell scripts)
  5. Black, Flake8 (Python)

  6. Prettier (TypeScript, JSON)

  7. Build Tests:

  8. MkDocs build (mkdocs build --strict)

  9. Container build (Dockerfile validation)

  10. Pre-commit Hooks:

  11. Trailing whitespace removal
  12. End-of-file fixes
  13. Large file check
  14. Merge conflict detection

  15. Private key detection

  16. Metadata Validation:

  17. All documentation files have valid frontmatter
  18. Metadata schema compliance

docs.title: Code Review Requirements
docs.text:
• Minimum Reviews: 1 approval required
  • Review Focus:
  • Accuracy of technical content
  • Consistency with existing style guide
  • Completeness of documentation
  • Grammar and clarity
  • Examples are correct and tested

docs.title: PR Description Template
docs.text:
## Summary
Brief description of changes

## Changes
- Bullet list of specific changes
- Include file changes, additions, deletions

## Testing
- [ ] MkDocs builds successfully
- [ ] Pre-commit hooks pass
- [ ] Manual testing performed (if applicable)

## Related Issues
Closes #<issue-number>

docs.title: PR Workflow
docs.text:
1. Create Branch:

git checkout -b feature/add-kubernetes-guide

2. Make Changes & Commit:

git add .
git commit -m "feat: add Kubernetes and Helm style guide"

3. Push & Create PR:

git push -u origin feature/add-kubernetes-guide
gh pr create --base main --title "feat: add Kubernetes guide" --body "..."

4. Address Review Feedback:

# Make requested changes
git add .
git commit -m "fix: address review feedback on Kubernetes guide"
git push

5. Merge (after approval):

# Squash and merge via GitHub UI or CLI
gh pr merge 123 --squash --delete-branch

docs.title: Merge Strategies
docs.text:
Squash Merge (Default):

  • Combines all commits into one
  • Keeps main branch history clean
  • Use for feature branches

Merge Commit:

  • Preserves all individual commits
  • Use for release branches
  • Use for hotfix branches

Rebase (Not Recommended):

  • Rewrites commit history
  • Avoid to maintain traceability

docs.title: Versioning Strategy
docs.text:
This project follows Semantic Versioning 2.0.0:

Format: MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH

  • MAJOR: Incompatible API changes, breaking changes to validation rules or container interface
  • MINOR: New features, language guides, or significant documentation additions (backward-compatible)
  • PATCH: Bug fixes, documentation improvements, dependency updates (backward-compatible)

Examples:

  • v1.0.0 → v2.0.0: Changed required metadata fields (breaking)
  • v1.0.0 → v1.1.0: Added PowerShell language guide (new feature)
  • v1.0.0 → v1.0.1: Fixed typo in Python guide (bug fix)

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text:
1. Prepare Release Branch:

git checkout develop
git pull origin develop
git checkout -b release/v1.3.0

2. Update Version and Changelog:

  • Update version in mkdocs.yml, pyproject.toml
  • Add release section to docs/changelog.md
  • Update any version references in documentation

3. Final Testing:

# Build and test documentation
uv run mkdocs build --strict

# Run all pre-commit hooks
pre-commit run --all-files

# Test container build
docker build -t coding-style-guide:v1.3.0 .

4. Create PR to Main:

git push -u origin release/v1.3.0
gh pr create --base main --title "Release v1.3.0"

5. Merge and Tag:

# Merge PR (via GitHub UI or CLI)
gh pr merge <pr-number> --merge --delete-branch

# Tag the release
git checkout main
git pull origin main
git tag v1.3.0
git push origin v1.3.0

6. Merge Back to Develop:

git checkout develop
git merge main
git push origin develop

7. Publish Release Notes:

# Create GitHub Release
gh release create v1.3.0 --title "Release v1.3.0" --notes-file CHANGELOG.md

docs.title: Pre-release Versions
docs.text:
For testing before official release:

  • Release Candidates: v1.3.0-rc.1, v1.3.0-rc.2
  • Beta: v1.3.0-beta.1
  • Alpha: v1.3.0-alpha.1

docs.title: Proposing Changes
docs.text:
1. Create GitHub Issue:

  • Use issue templates (feature request, bug report, documentation)
  • Clearly describe the problem or enhancement
  • Provide examples and use cases

2. Discussion:

  • Maintainers review and provide feedback
  • Community members can comment and vote
  • Decision made within 7 days for features, 48 hours for bugs

3. Approval:

  • Issue labeled as approved or wontfix
  • Assigned to milestone (if approved)

docs.title: Breaking Changes
docs.text:
Definition: Changes that require users to modify their code or workflows.

Examples:

  • Removing or renaming metadata fields
  • Changing validation rules that fail existing code
  • Removing support for a language version

Process:

  1. Proposal: Create RFC (Request for Comments) issue
  2. Discussion: Minimum 14-day community feedback period
  3. Vote: Maintainers vote on approval
  4. Deprecation: Announce in changelog, provide migration guide
  5. Implementation: MAJOR version bump required

docs.title: Deprecation Policy
docs.text:
Timeline:

  • Announce: Deprecation announced in MINOR release
  • Warning Period: Minimum 3 months (or 2 MINOR releases, whichever is longer)
  • Removal: Removed in next MAJOR release

Communication:

  • Changelog entry with deprecation notice
  • Migration guide in documentation
  • Warning messages in validation tools (if applicable)

docs.title: Repository Roles
docs.text:
Maintainers (Write Access):

  • Approve and merge pull requests
  • Create releases
  • Manage issues and milestones
  • Push to develop branch (via PR only)

Contributors (Read Access):

  • Fork repository
  • Create pull requests
  • Comment on issues and PRs
  • No direct push access

docs.title: Becoming a Maintainer
docs.text:
Requirements:

  • Consistent, high-quality contributions (minimum 10 merged PRs)
  • Deep understanding of style guide principles
  • Active participation in reviews and discussions
  • Demonstrated commitment to project goals

Process:

  • Nominated by existing maintainer
  • Approved by majority vote of maintainers
  • Added to CODEOWNERS and granted write access

docs.title: Code of Conduct
docs.text:
All contributors must follow the Code of Conduct:

  • Be respectful and inclusive
  • Assume good intent
  • Focus on what's best for the community
  • Accept constructive criticism gracefully
  • Show empathy toward other community members

docs.title: Decision-Making Process
docs.text:
Minor Decisions (documentation fixes, dependency updates):

  • Single maintainer approval sufficient
  • Merged within 48 hours if no objections

Major Decisions (new language guides, breaking changes):

  • Require 2+ maintainer approvals
  • Minimum 7-day discussion period
  • Majority vote of active maintainers

Urgent Decisions (security fixes, critical bugs):

  • Single maintainer can expedite
  • Post-facto review within 24 hours

docs.title: Continuous Improvement
docs.text:
This governance model evolves based on:

  • Team feedback: Regular retrospectives on process effectiveness
  • Growth: Adapt as contributor base and repository complexity grow
  • Best practices: Incorporate learnings from other open-source projects

Proposing Governance Changes:

  1. Open issue with governance label
  2. Minimum 14-day discussion period
  3. Requires 75% maintainer approval
  4. Document change in this file and announce in changelog

docs.text:

docs.title: Core Principles
docs.text: The Dukes Engineering Style Guide is built on core principles that prioritize automation, AI integration, consistency, and maintainability. These principles guide every decision in the style guide and shape how teams write, review, and maintain code.

docs.title: Guiding Philosophy
docs.text:
Code is read far more often than it is written. This style guide optimizes for:

  • Readability: Code should be immediately understandable by humans and AI assistants
  • Consistency: Uniform patterns across languages, projects, and teams
  • Automation: Enforce standards automatically, not through manual review
  • AI-Optimization: Structure code and metadata to maximize AI assistant effectiveness
  • Maintainability: Code should be easy to modify, refactor, and extend

docs.title: 1. Automation Over Manual Enforcement
docs.text: Principle: Standards must be automatically enforceable through tooling. Manual code review should focus on logic, architecture, and design—not formatting or style violations.

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
• Consistency: Automated tools apply standards uniformly across all code
  • Efficiency: Developers spend time solving problems, not debating formatting
  • Early Detection: Issues caught in IDE or pre-commit, not in CI or code review
  • Objective Standards: No subjective interpretation of style rules

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
Pre-commit Hooks: Enforce standards before code reaches version control

# .pre-commit-config.yaml
repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/psf/black
    hooks:
      - id: black        # Python formatting
  - repo: https://github.com/pycqa/flake8
    hooks:
      - id: flake8       # Python linting

CI/CD Validation: Fail builds on standard violations

# .github/workflows/ci.yml
- name: Validate coding standards
  uses: tydukes/coding-style-guide/.github/actions/validate@v1.0.0
  with:
    mode: validate

IDE Integration: Real-time feedback during development

  • VSCode: .vscode/settings.json with format-on-save
  • JetBrains: EditorConfig integration
  • Vim: ALE or CoC with language servers

docs.title: Tools by Language
docs.text: Language Formatter Linter Type Checker Python Black Flake8, Pylint mypy TypeScript Prettier ESLint tsc Terraform terraform fmt tflint terraform validate Bash shfmt shellcheck - YAML prettier yamllint -

docs.title: 2. AI-Friendly Metadata
docs.text: Principle: All code modules must include structured metadata that helps AI assistants understand context, purpose, dependencies, and usage patterns.

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
• AI Assistant Effectiveness: Metadata helps AI understand code intent and relationships
  • Automated Documentation: Metadata enables auto-generated documentation
  • Dependency Tracking: Clear declaration of module dependencies and requirements
  • Searchability: Structured metadata improves code search and discovery

docs.title: Metadata Schema
docs.text:
Every module includes a @module metadata block:

Python Example:

"""
@module user_authentication
@description Handles user authentication, session management, and JWT token generation
@dependencies fastapi, pyjwt, passlib, python-dotenv
@version 1.2.0
@author Tyler Dukes
@last_updated 2025-10-27
@security_classification internal
@api_endpoints POST /auth/login, POST /auth/logout, POST /auth/refresh
"""

import jwt
from fastapi import APIRouter

Terraform Example:

/**
 * @module vpc
 * @description Creates VPC with public/private subnets, NAT gateways, and route tables
 * @dependencies aws_vpc, aws_subnet, aws_nat_gateway
 * @version 2.1.0
 * @author Tyler Dukes
 * @last_updated 2025-10-27
 * @terraform_version >= 1.0
 */

resource "aws_vpc" "main" {
  cidr_block = var.vpc_cidr
}

docs.title: Benefits for AI Assistants
docs.text:
• Context Awareness: AI knows module purpose without reading entire codebase
  • Accurate Suggestions: Dependencies help AI suggest compatible libraries
  • Version Compatibility: AI can warn about version mismatches
  • Security Context: Classification helps AI avoid suggesting insecure patterns

docs.title: 3. Consistency Across Languages
docs.text: Principle: While each language has unique conventions, overarching patterns (naming, structure, documentation) remain consistent across the codebase.

docs.title: Cross-Language Standards
docs.text:
Naming Conventions:

  • Variables/Functions: snake_case (Python, Bash), camelCase (TypeScript, Java)
  • Constants: UPPER_SNAKE_CASE (all languages)
  • Classes: PascalCase (all languages)
  • Files: snake_case.ext (Python: user_auth.py, TypeScript: user_auth.ts)

Directory Structure:

src/
├── core/              # Core business logic
├── api/               # API endpoints
├── services/          # External service integrations
└── utils/             # Utility functions

tests/
├── unit/              # Unit tests
├── integration/       # Integration tests
└── e2e/               # End-to-end tests

Documentation Structure:

  • Module-level docstrings/comments at file top
  • Function/method documentation before definition
  • Inline comments only for complex logic
  • README.md in each major directory

docs.title: Why Consistency Matters
docs.text:
• Cognitive Load: Developers switch between languages seamlessly
  • Onboarding: New team members learn patterns once, apply everywhere
  • Tooling: Consistent patterns enable shared validation scripts
  • AI Assistance: AI learns patterns faster with consistency

docs.title: 4. Semantic Versioning
docs.text: Principle: All modules, libraries, and the style guide itself follow strict semantic versioning (MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH).

docs.title: Versioning Rules
docs.text:
• MAJOR: Breaking changes to API, interface, or validation rules
  • MINOR: New features, language guides, backward-compatible additions
  • PATCH: Bug fixes, documentation improvements, dependency updates

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
Breaking Change (MAJOR: 1.0.0 → 2.0.0):

  • Changed required metadata fields (breaks existing validation)
  • Removed support for Python 3.8
  • Changed Terraform module variable names

New Feature (MINOR: 1.0.0 → 1.1.0):

  • Added new language guide (PowerShell)
  • Added new validation mode (security scanning)
  • Added optional metadata fields

Bug Fix (PATCH: 1.0.0 → 1.0.1):

  • Fixed typo in documentation
  • Corrected linter configuration
  • Updated dependency versions

docs.title: Version Tags
docs.text:
# Releases
git tag v1.0.0
git tag v1.1.0
git tag v2.0.0

# Pre-releases
git tag v1.0.0-rc.1
git tag v1.0.0-beta.2

docs.title: 5. Repository Flexibility
docs.text: Principle: Support both monorepo and multi-repo patterns. Language guides are modular and can be used independently or together.

docs.title: Monorepo Benefits
docs.text:
• Atomic cross-service changes
  • Shared tooling and validation
  • Single source of truth
  • Simplified CI/CD

docs.title: Multi-Repo Benefits
docs.text:
• Clear ownership boundaries
  • Independent release cycles
  • Smaller, focused repositories
  • Granular access control

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
The style guide itself is a monorepo but provides guidance for both patterns. Each language guide can be:

  • Referenced independently via documentation portal
  • Integrated into any repository via container or GitHub Action
  • Adopted incrementally (start with one language, expand over time)

See Repository Structure for detailed guidance.

docs.title: Readability First
docs.text:
Code clarity trumps cleverness. Prefer explicit, verbose code over compact, obscure solutions.

Good:

def calculate_user_discount(user_tier: str, purchase_amount: float) -> float:
    """Calculate discount based on user tier and purchase amount."""
    if user_tier == "premium":
        return purchase_amount * 0.20
    elif user_tier == "standard":
        return purchase_amount * 0.10
    return 0.0

Bad:

def calc_disc(t, a): return a * (0.2 if t == "p" else 0.1 if t == "s" else 0)

docs.title: Security by Default
docs.text:
Secure coding patterns are mandatory, not optional.

  • No hardcoded secrets (use environment variables, secret managers)
  • Input validation on all external data
  • Least privilege access (IAM, database permissions)
  • Dependency scanning (Dependabot, Snyk)
  • Security linting (bandit for Python, tfsec for Terraform)

docs.title: Test-Driven Quality
docs.text:
All code must be testable and tested.

  • Unit tests for business logic (80%+ coverage)
  • Integration tests for API endpoints
  • E2E tests for critical user flows
  • Tests run in CI before merge

docs.title: Documentation as Code
docs.text:
Documentation lives with code and is versioned together.

  • README.md in every directory
  • API documentation generated from code (OpenAPI, JSDoc)
  • Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) for major decisions
  • MkDocs for comprehensive project documentation

docs.title: How Principles Work Together
docs.text:
These principles reinforce each other:

  1. Automation ensures consistency is maintained automatically
  2. AI-friendly metadata enables better automation through AI-assisted tooling
  3. Semantic versioning supports repository flexibility by enabling safe upgrades
  4. Consistency improves readability across languages and teams
  5. Readability enhances AI-friendliness by making intent clear

docs.title: Implementation Checklist
docs.text:
When adopting this style guide:

  • [ ] Set up pre-commit hooks for automated formatting
  • [ ] Configure CI/CD to validate standards on every PR
  • [ ] Add metadata blocks to all existing modules
  • [ ] Adopt semantic versioning for all libraries and modules
  • [ ] Document repository structure (monorepo vs multi-repo)
  • [ ] Enable IDE auto-formatting on save
  • [ ] Train team on core principles and tooling
  • [ ] Create CONTRIBUTING.md with standards reference
  • [ ] Set up Dependabot or similar for dependency updates
  • [ ] Add security scanning to CI pipeline

docs.title: Evolution of Principles
docs.text:
These principles evolve based on:

  • Team Feedback: Practical experience reveals needed adjustments
  • Technology Changes: New languages, frameworks, and tools require updates
  • AI Advancement: As AI capabilities grow, metadata schemas adapt
  • Security Landscape: New threats require updated security principles

Propose changes via pull request with clear rationale. Major principle changes trigger MAJOR version bumps.

docs.title: References
docs.text:

  • The Zen of Python
  • Google Style Guides
  • Infrastructure as Code Best Practices

docs.title: This Style Guide's Structure (Monorepo)
docs.text:
This style guide itself is organized as a monorepo containing all language guides, templates, schemas, and tooling in a single repository. This approach enables:

  • Centralized versioning: All guides evolve together with unified semantic versioning
  • Shared tooling: Validation scripts, CI/CD pipelines, and container images are reused
  • Consistency: Cross-references between guides remain in-sync
  • Single source of truth: Documentation portal builds from one repository

docs.text:
coding-style-guide/

│   ├── 01_overview/               # General principles and governance

│   │   ├── typescript.md
│   │   └── ...
│   ├── 03_metadata_schema/        # Schema documentation
│   ├── 04_templates/              # Document templates
│   ├── 05_ci_cd/                  # CI/CD patterns
│   ├── 06_container/              # Container usage
│   ├── 07_integration/            # Integration guides

├── .github/                        # GitHub workflows and actions
│   ├── workflows/                 # CI/CD workflows
│   │   ├── ci.yml

docs.title: Why Monorepo for This Project?
docs.text:
The monorepo structure is ideal for this style guide because:

  1. Unified releases: All guides release together with consistent versioning (v1.0.0)
  2. Cross-language consistency: Python, Terraform, and Bash guides reference common metadata schemas
  3. Shared validation: All languages use the same metadata validation scripts
  4. Simplified CI/CD: One pipeline validates all content
  5. Single documentation site: MkDocs builds all guides into one portal

docs.title: Recommended Repository Structures
docs.text: When implementing these standards in your projects, choose the organizational pattern that fits your team and project needs.

docs.title: Pattern 1: Monorepo (Recommended for Multi-Service Projects)
docs.text:
Use when:

  • Managing multiple related services (microservices)
  • Sharing common libraries or infrastructure code
  • Team needs atomic cross-service changes
  • Unified deployment pipelines are valuable

Structure:

project-name/
├── services/
│   ├── api/
│   │   ├── src/
│   │   ├── tests/
│   │   ├── README.md
│   │   └── pyproject.toml
│   ├── worker/
│   │   ├── src/
│   │   ├── tests/
│   │   └── README.md
│   └── frontend/
│       ├── src/
│       ├── tests/
│       └── package.json
├── infrastructure/
│   ├── terraform/
│   │   ├── modules/
│   │   └── environments/
│   └── kubernetes/
│       ├── base/
│       └── overlays/
├── shared/
│   ├── libraries/
│   └── schemas/
├── docs/
│   ├── architecture/
│   ├── runbooks/
│   └── index.md
├── .github/
│   └── workflows/
├── Makefile
└── README.md

Benefits:

  • Atomic commits across services
  • Shared dependency management
  • Single source of truth
  • Easier refactoring

Trade-offs:

  • Larger repository size
  • CI/CD must handle selective builds
  • Access control is all-or-nothing

docs.title: Pattern 2: Multi-Repo (Recommended for Independent Services)
docs.text:
Use when:

  • Services are independently deployed
  • Different teams own different services
  • Fine-grained access control needed
  • Services have different release cadences

Structure (per repository):

service-name/
├── src/
│   ├── main/
│   └── test/
├── docs/
│   ├── api/
│   ├── deployment/
│   └── README.md
├── infrastructure/
│   └── terraform/
├── .github/
│   └── workflows/
├── scripts/
├── Dockerfile
├── Makefile
└── README.md

Benefits:

  • Clear ownership boundaries
  • Independent release cycles
  • Smaller, focused repositories
  • Granular access control

Trade-offs:

  • Cross-service changes require multiple PRs
  • Dependency version mismatches possible
  • Duplicated CI/CD configuration

docs.title: Pattern 3: Hybrid (Infrastructure Monorepo + Service Multi-Repo)
docs.text:
Use when:

  • Infrastructure is shared across services
  • Services are independently owned
  • Centralized infrastructure governance needed

Infrastructure Repository:

infrastructure/
├── terraform/
│   ├── modules/
│   │   ├── networking/
│   │   ├── compute/
│   │   └── database/
│   └── environments/
│       ├── dev/
│       ├── staging/
│       └── prod/
├── kubernetes/
│   ├── clusters/
│   └── shared-manifests/
├── ansible/
│   └── playbooks/
├── docs/
└── README.md

Service Repositories:

  • Each service in its own repository
  • Services reference infrastructure modules via Git tags
  • Terraform modules versioned and published

Benefits:

  • Centralized infrastructure governance
  • Service independence
  • Reusable infrastructure modules

Trade-offs:

  • Coordination needed for infrastructure changes
  • Module versioning overhead

docs.title: Directory Standards
docs.text: Regardless of organizational pattern, follow these directory conventions:

docs.title: Required Top-Level Directories
docs.text:
project/
├── src/           # Source code (or services/ for monorepo)
├── tests/         # Tests (mirror src/ structure)
├── docs/          # Documentation (MkDocs recommended)
├── scripts/       # Automation scripts
└── infrastructure/ # IaC code (Terraform, K8s manifests)

docs.title: Optional Directories
docs.text:
├── .github/       # GitHub-specific (workflows, CODEOWNERS)
├── templates/     # Project templates
├── examples/      # Usage examples
├── tools/         # Development tools
└── config/        # Configuration files

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Lowercase with hyphens: my-service/, api-gateway/
  • Descriptive names: user-authentication-service/ not service-1/
  • Consistent plurals: services/, modules/, scripts/

docs.title: 1. Colocate Related Files
docs.text:
Keep related files together:

src/
└── user-authentication/
    ├── service.py          # Core implementation
    ├── service_test.py     # Tests
    ├── README.md           # Module documentation
    └── schema.json         # Data schema

docs.title: 2. Separate Source from Configuration
docs.text:
project/
├── src/                    # Application code
├── config/                 # Configuration files
│   ├── development.yaml
│   ├── staging.yaml
│   └── production.yaml
└── infrastructure/         # Infrastructure as Code

docs.title: 3. Use Clear Test Directories
docs.text:
Option A: Mirrored Structure (Recommended for Python, TypeScript)

src/
├── api/
│   ├── users.py
│   └── posts.py
tests/
├── api/
│   ├── test_users.py
│   └── test_posts.py

Option B: Colocated Tests (Recommended for Go, Rust)

src/
├── api/
│   ├── users.go
│   ├── users_test.go
│   ├── posts.go
│   └── posts_test.go

docs.title: 4. Documentation Structure
docs.text:
Use MkDocs-compatible structure:

docs/
├── index.md               # Home page
├── getting-started/
│   ├── installation.md
│   └── quickstart.md
├── guides/
│   ├── deployment.md
│   └── configuration.md
├── api/
│   └── reference.md
└── architecture/
    ├── overview.md
    └── decisions/         # ADRs (Architecture Decision Records)

docs.title: Terraform/Terragrunt
docs.text:
infrastructure/
├── terraform/
│   ├── modules/           # Reusable modules
│   │   ├── vpc/
│   │   ├── ecs-service/
│   │   └── rds/
│   └── environments/      # Environment-specific configs
│       ├── dev/
│       │   ├── terragrunt.hcl
│       │   └── terraform.tfvars
│       ├── staging/
│       └── prod/
└── docs/
    └── infrastructure.md

infrastructure/
├── kubernetes/
│   ├── base/              # Kustomize base
│   │   ├── deployment.yaml
│   │   └── service.yaml
│   └── overlays/          # Environment overlays

│       ├── staging/
│       └── prod/

.github/
├── workflows/
│   ├── ci.yml             # Continuous integration
│   ├── cd-dev.yml         # Deploy to dev
│   ├── cd-prod.yml        # Deploy to production
│   └── validate.yml       # Pre-commit validation
├── actions/               # Custom actions

docs.title: GitLab CI
docs.text:
.gitlab/
├── ci/
│   ├── lint.yml
│   ├── test.yml
│   └── deploy.yml
└── .gitlab-ci.yml         # Main pipeline config

docs.title: Branch Structure (GitFlow)
docs.text:
main                       # Production-ready code
├── develop                # Integration branch
├── feature/               # Feature branches
│   ├── add-user-auth
│   └── improve-logging
├── fix/                   # Bug fix branches
│   └── fix-login-error
└── release/               # Release preparation
    └── v1.2.0

docs.title: Tagging Convention
docs.text:
• Releases: v1.0.0, v1.1.0, v2.0.0 (semantic versioning)
  • Pre-releases: v1.0.0-rc.1, v1.0.0-beta.2
  • Module versions: terraform/vpc/v1.0.0

docs.title: Makefile Organization
docs.text:
Centralize common tasks in a Makefile:

.PHONY: help lint test build deploy clean

help:
 @echo "Available targets:"
 @echo "  lint      - Run linters"
 @echo "  test      - Run tests"
 @echo "  build     - Build container"
 @echo "  deploy    - Deploy to environment"

lint:
 @pre-commit run --all-files

test:
 @pytest tests/

build:
 @docker build -t myapp:latest .

deploy:
 @./scripts/deploy.sh $(ENV)

docs.title: From Multi-Repo to Monorepo
docs.text:
1. Create new monorepo structure
  2. Import each repository as subdirectory preserving history:

bash git subtree add --prefix services/api api-repo main

  1. Update CI/CD for monorepo patterns (selective builds)
  2. Migrate documentation to unified MkDocs

docs.title: From Monorepo to Multi-Repo
docs.text:
1. Extract each service with history:

bash git subtree split --prefix services/api -b api-split

  1. Create new repository from split branch
  2. Update cross-repo references to use Git tags
  3. Set up cross-repo CI/CD coordination

docs.title: Language Overview
docs.text: Ansible is an agentless configuration management and automation platform that uses YAML-based playbooks to define infrastructure as code. Modern Ansible development emphasizes collections over standalone roles.

docs.title: Key Characteristics
docs.text:
• Paradigm: Declarative configuration management
  • Language: YAML with Jinja2 templating
  • Architecture: Agentless (SSH/WinRM)
  • Version Support: Ansible 2.15.x through 2.17.x
  • Modern Approach: Collections-first (not standalone roles)

docs.title: Primary Use Cases
docs.text:
• Configuration management
  • Application deployment
  • Infrastructure provisioning
  • Security and compliance automation
  • Orchestration and workflow automation

docs.title: Collections-First Approach
docs.text:
Use Ansible Collections instead of standalone roles:

# Good - Using collection
---
- name: Configure web servers
  hosts: webservers

- name: Configure web servers

    - name: Deploy website content

docs.title: Variable Precedence
docs.text:
Ansible variable precedence (lowest to highest):

  1. Command line values (--extra-vars)
  2. Role defaults (defaults/main.yml)
  3. Inventory file or script group vars
  4. Inventory group_vars/all
  5. Playbook group_vars/all
  6. Inventory group_vars/*
  7. Playbook group_vars/*
  8. Inventory file or script host vars
  9. Inventory host_vars/*
  10. Playbook host_vars/*
  11. Host facts / cached set_facts
  12. Play vars
  13. Play vars_prompt
  14. Play vars_files
  15. Role vars (vars/main.yml)
  16. Block vars (only for tasks in block)
  17. Task vars (only for the task)
  18. Include vars
  19. Set_facts / registered vars
  20. Role (and include_role) params
  21. Include params
  22. Extra vars (always win precedence)
# Example showing variable override
---
- name: Variable precedence example
  hosts: all
  vars:
    app_port: 8080  # Play vars
  tasks:
    - name: Show port (will use 9000 from task vars)
      ansible.builtin.debug:
        msg: "Port is {{ app_port }}"
      vars:
        app_port: 9000  # Task vars (higher precedence)

{# templates/nginx.conf.j2 #}
user {{ nginx_user }};
worker_processes {{ nginx_worker_processes }};

events {
    worker_connections {{ nginx_worker_connections | default(1024) }};
}

http {
    include /etc/nginx/mime.types;
    default_type application/octet-stream;

    {% for server in nginx_servers %}
    server {
        listen {{ server.port | default(80) }};
        server_name {{ server.name }};
        root {{ server.document_root }};

        {% if server.ssl_enabled | default(false) %}
        ssl_certificate {{ server.ssl_cert }};
        ssl_certificate_key {{ server.ssl_key }};
        {% endif %}

        location / {
            try_files $uri $uri/ =404;
        }
    }
    {% endfor %}
}

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:
---
- name: Error handling examples
  hosts: all
  tasks:
    # Ignore errors
    - name: Try to stop service (may not exist)
      ansible.builtin.service:
        name: optional-service
        state: stopped
      ignore_errors: true

    # Conditional failure
    - name: Check disk space
      ansible.builtin.shell: df -h / | awk 'NR==2 {print $5}' | sed 's/%//'
      register: disk_usage
      failed_when: disk_usage.stdout | int > 90
      changed_when: false

    # Custom failure message
    - name: Validate configuration
      ansible.builtin.command: validate-config.sh
      register: validation
      failed_when:
        - validation.rc != 0
        - "'CRITICAL' in validation.stderr"

    # Block with rescue
    - name: Deploy with rollback
      block:
        - name: Deploy new version
          ansible.builtin.copy:
            src: app-v2.jar
            dest: /opt/app/app.jar
          notify: Restart app

        - name: Run health check
          ansible.builtin.uri:
            url: http://localhost:8080/health
            status_code: 200
          retries: 5
          delay: 10

      rescue:
        - name: Rollback to previous version
          ansible.builtin.copy:
            src: app-v1.jar
            dest: /opt/app/app.jar
          notify: Restart app

        - name: Send alert
          ansible.builtin.debug:
            msg: "Deployment failed, rolled back to v1"

      always:
        - name: Cleanup temp files
          ansible.builtin.file:
            path: /tmp/deploy
            state: absent
